content.description:
This climb is mostly the same as the toprope route "Jump Start" 5.11a in the Newfoundland Climbing Guide. From the FA:

"From the topo, and from my recollection, The Art of Body Karate looks to be around where Jump Start is. Or slightly to the left? I think it’s the thin seam just to the left of Jump Start. I recall it involves some thin finger jamming and some very cool high-kick body karate moves (hence the name)"

-Greg Foote



Gear anchor, to toprope. Or use a very long cordalette to equalize two of the many top bolts on adjacent climbs. 

Standard rack with an emphasis on small cams, if leading.

More overhanging face climbing past flaring horizontal cracks. Not a safe trad lead, at least one person has decked and broken bones after a lead attempt. A good candidate for bolting.




Top anchor

Climb the crack in the corner past a low crux to easier climbing near the top.

Rack up to 3". Anchors at the top but they are very far back so you need a lot of cord.

Pull through the roof from the ground on the left hand side and either go up a little before trending right or traversing immediately. Use the cracks and tension to work your way to the top. Super strenuous for the grade but no particularly hard moves.

Rack to 3" with an optional bigger piece at the top. Gear anchor.

Overhanging face climbing past flaring horizontal cracks. Probably not a safe trad lead, better to rappel down it first unless you can confidently downclimb or solo 5.11.


Toprope Anchor

Climb the balancy, shallow crack next to the corner

Top rope only. The anchors are a long way back from the edge so long cord or slings are needed.

The double crack system just right of the large ledge. The start can consist of a left sidepull for the left hand leaning the body with the right hip to the wall, a right jug on the horizontal crack, and feet on some of the features underneath. The climb then proceeds to the anchor, following the right crack as the holds get slightly bigger at the end, with pebbly footholds on the way up.



Start to the right of the ledge of "Little Jack's Corner" and to the left of the start for "Grunt". 


There is currently a two-bolt anchor at the top for top-roping/anchor set up. This anchor can be set with two one-foot slings and four (locking?) carabiners, or a similar configuration with other gear such as a cordelette and/or sling webbing.

To lead the route, standard trad rack, with an emphasis on small cams.

Climb the corner crack starting from the big, elevated ledge. A decent beginner lead. 


Standard Rack, top bolts for toproping.

This route is accessed by rappelling through a gully to a small ledge about 20 feet above the ocean. 
  
 Walk 10 feet left along this ledge then follow the line of jugs up the middle of the face. Move slightly left to pull the small roof and continue on jugs to the top.

This route is located directly behind Bloodbath on the opposite side of the Beamer. Walk past the Blood Bath Traverse up the slope to the edge of the Beamer. Walk right along it until you can scramble down to a ledge with a gully leading into the ocean. Set a gear anchor in this gully and rappel down to the ledge where 2 routes can be accessed.
Standard rack to 3 inches + RP's. The pro is a bit sketchy. Gear anchors for top and gully rappel.

Start by reaching to the back of a body sized crack for a good hold and climb up into the double crack system. Hug the two cracks, lay back or use your crack climbing skills to get to the top.

Immediately to the right of the Blood Bath dihedral
Rack up to 4". Anchors on top are very far back so you need a lot of cord.

Follow the sharp crack straight up.  
 Connect to a large hand ledge and two horizontal cracks.  
 Continue up the vertical crack until the bolt anchor is just to your left. 
 Very short but very easy to access with quick scramble to the anchor.  
 A great climb for beginners who haven't climbed outside. 
 This is one of the shortest and least intimidating crags I've been at.

Walk out to the far far end of the beamer in Flatrock, past the "Two Boulders". There is either an easy scramble down (left access, from the anchors) or a light hike around the other side (right access). Very close to 'UV Ray Wall' as well for other sport climbing.
2 bolts at the anchor. Trad rack or Top Rope only

Thrash up the flared chimney, which becomes easier as you approach the top. 



Bolted anchor set back over the edge, likely a well protected lead with a standard rack (I may have lead it years ago).

Climb side pulls and crimps up the face to some reachy moves from the mid point up to a good hold before the finish.

A few feet to the right of Shake 'n' Bake starting under a good flake for your right hand.
Top rope only. Anchors very close to the edge.

Climb up a a 10 foot face with a hand crack to your right. 
 Reach a series of small ledges leaning rightward into a sloping dihedral. 
 There are some alternate starts that finish at the same anchor that will be added later. 
 To the left a series of jugs heading up and to the right, meeting the ledges. 
 To the right, a series of smaller features goes up and to the left meeting a horizontal ledge and crack. Finish along the ledges, or stay right and lean off the arete on small careful footing.

2 bolts at the anchor. Trad or Top Rope only.

A small area with short cliffs that is still very popular because it is easily accessible and many of the climbs can be top-roped. The area receives afternoon sun but you have to be careful as when the sea is rough belayers can easily be caught by the waves.
